The singer doesn't have a powerful voice, but he is a capable singer. <br /> <br />Assuming arguendo that the band wrote all of the material on the album, then lyrically they are pretty solid, but could use some seasoning and additional life experience to fire their creative juices and tighten loose lyrics that are none the less interesting. <br /> <br />For my taste, \\"Riot Van\\" is the most interesting song on the album.  It is essentially the story of teenagers having their chops busted by the cops, and a bit of a universal story because of it, but the song is also revealing because while it is quite interesting lyrically, the ending is weak.  Endings are the band's weakness at this time, and the thing that I believe a world class producer could and should fix in a second album. <br /><br />As a debut effort, I'm impressed because there is a unique sound here, but a touch of formula, just a touch, would bring these guys up a level. <br /> <br />Is it the second coming of The Beatles, no, unless you compare the sales in Europe followed by what looks like a fairly quick catching on in the US. <br /> <br />Does the band have the potential to become a great rock band, yes because they do have a unique sound, and they have an ability to turn an interesting phrase which is the first step towards pop rock greatness. <br /> <br />Other highlights of the Album would be \\"When the Sun Goes Down\\" which has a reference to \\"Roxanne\\" that works because it turns that songs themes on its ear. <br /> <br />\\"Red light indicates doors are secured\\" is very interesting rythymically, but I have to also say that the rythym of the song sounds a lot like a riff from a song by a great New York Jam Band, \\"The Niche\\"  who you can hear on their website [...]  Just an observation that leads me to believe that the rythymic influences of funk/jam are strong in the album. <br /> <br />\\"Mardy Bum\\" with its catchy use of the word \\"argumentative\\" is probably the best pop rock song on the album and again quite strong rythymically. <br /> <br />The rest of the album is pretty good too to be honest, and the band at their age with such a solid rythym section shows a great deal of promise.  \\"A Certain Romance\\" is a pretty good song indeed, but very British, and clearly one of the songs that lets you know that these guys are very Tongue in Cheek. <br /> <br />Remember, humor in music is a good thing and I don't think these guys have forgotten that.  In fact, there isn't anything wrong with good drinking music which is what the album is in the end.  They are decidedly a great bar band, which is where all great bands really need to start. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />
B000ELIVB0|4.0|Best known for their beautifully tender Heartbeats (touchingly covered by Jose Gonzalez and used during Sony's Bravia television campaign featuring thousands of super balls filmed bouncing down a Chicago street), Swedish brother and sister duo The Knife have followed up on the vibrant electro styles of 2005's Deep Cuts with an album far more sinister and shadowy. Keeping with their surreal style, Karin and Olof Dreijer began recording Silent Shout in an abandoned carbon dioxide factory before relocating to the underground catacombs of an ancient Stockholm church. Karin's squeaky yet heartbreaking vocals have been thoroughly manipulated on Silent Shout, with the Scandinavian pop overtones of Deep Cuts being replaced by a much darker vibe. The glacial synthesizers of The Captain are as sharp as the band's name suggest, while the frenetic We Share Our Mother's Health - complete with Teutonic vocals announcing `We come down from the north' - sounds like an electro take on Led Zeppelin's Immigrant Song. Although the filtered effects and overwhelming darkness of many of the songs make it frequently opaque, Silent Shout's highlight Marble House lightens the mood a little. Featuring Swedish musician Jay Jay Johanson as a guest singer, this future single finds his tender vocals offsetting Karin's creepy sounds. The exciting Madonna-versus-Royksopp style of Marble House, the delicate From Off To On and the skittery beats of the opening title track mean that although Silent Shout has less commercial zest, its enlightened and progressive nature has the power to both confound and delight.

B000EPR7NE|5.0|Hans Zimmer is my favorite score composer.  I find that when I first listen to a new score of his I anticipate it being like his other scores that are favorites of mine.  Usually I'm pleasantly surprised by his forays into new styles.  This was certainly the case with The Da Vinci Code.  If I were to compare this score to others of his I would say it's closest to Thin Red Line, Hannibal, and Batman Begins.  It's definitely unlike Zimmer's action scores (King Arthur, Gladiator, Crimson Tide, or The Peacemaker), it's much more etherial at times and intense at others without being overpowering.    This score captures the mystery, intrigue, and suspense of both the novel and the movie.    The emotional track #13 \\"CheValiers de Sangreal\\" is certainly the crowning achievement of the entire score.  This track will likely be used in movie trailers for years to come as Zimmer's masterpiece \\"Journey To The Line\\" is.  The CD is worth purchasing for this track alone.    This score merits serious Oscar consideration.  There's nothing out this year that even begins to compares to it.
B00005JOIH|5.0|One of the greatest ironies of international politics in the wake of World War II is that you can make an argument that the most fascist nation on the face of the planet is the state of Israel. This will strike most people as an oxymoronic claim because they will associate fascism with Nazi Germany, which means the Holocaust and the attempted extermination of every Jew in Europe. But as a political ideology that existed outside Hitler's Third Reich such as Mussolini's Italy, Franco's Spain, and Peron's Argentina, fascism had a specific dynamic that viewed life as an ongoing \\"struggle\\" for \\"order.\\" Mussolini was always proclaiming a struggle for wheat or whatnot, and we all know about his ability to get the trains to run on time. This dynamic stands in remarked contrast to the Whig-Liberal dynamic of \\"liberty\\" and \\"property,\\" but if you recall the Cold War then you can appreciate how fascist elements worked there way in American politics as well. In Israel, where everybody considers themself to be soldiers, life is indeed such a struggle more so than any other nation you can name.<br /><br />The argument that in its struggle to survive the state of Israel has become more like its enemy than it would wish to be in a better world is at the core of Steven Spielberg's \\"Munich.\\" The massacre of the Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich is presented as the opening act on the modern age of terrorism, and you do not need the camera's final shot to show the World Trade Center in the distance to know that this drama is still ongoing. Ultimately, the film is not about what happened at Munich but how the Israeli government responded. There is no small degree of symbolism in which some athletes innocently help the Palestinian members of Black September into the Olympic village. Actually footage of the coverage of the hostage drama, including Jim McCay's unforgettable announcement to the world that \\"they're all gone\\" is mixed with shots of what the terrorists are doing. But the actual deaths of the terrorists and their hostages comes later in the film, as the main character keeps recalling the events as justification for what he has to do and later for what he has done.<br /><br />Fulfilling the injunction of an eye for an eye in the Torah, the Israeli government comes up with a list of eleven Palestinians to die for the eleven Israelis murdered in Munich. Avner (Eric Bana), a former bodyguard to Prime Minister Golda Meir (Lynn Cohen) is made the leader of a secret and unofficial group that will track down the Palestinians and kill them. His only link to the government is Ephraim (Geoffrey Rush), who will make sure there is enough money to get the job done. Working with Avner are Hans (Hanns Zischler), who can forge necessary documents, Steve (Daniel Craig), who is always eager to pull the trigger, Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), who has gone from making toys to building bombs, and Carl (Ciaran Hinds), who cleans up the evidence and who is the only member of the group to question what they are doing.<br /><br />We question because like the characters in the film we have to take at face value that these men need to be killed. But the first has translated \\"The Arabian Nights\\" into Italian. The second asks the world to note how many Palestinians have been killed by Israelis since Munich. They are not the terrorists, but they do share their ethnicity and perhaps their politics. But what about a man kissing his daughter goodbye makes him a terrorist? Avner gets information about where to find his targets from Louis (Mathieu Amalric), a Frenchman who could be connected to anybody from the C.I.A. to Mossad for all Avner knows. Meanwhile, as Avner and his men cross more names off of their list Black September is escalating its attacks, and there comes a point at which the hunters become the hunted, not that this stops them from pushing on with their missions.<br /><br />\\"Munich\\" is inspired by real events rather than an attempt to document what the Israelis did in response to the Olympic massacre. What I know about the true history is that they succeeded in killing many of their targets, who may or may not have been directly involved in Munich. The screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth, based on the book \\"Vengeance\\" by George Jonas, goes out of its way to make the attendant ironies of this endeavor palatable. While they use the same weapons in an effort to terrorize the terrorists, what separates Avner's group from their targets is their avoidance of collateral damage, which becomes impossible. But the pivotal scene in the film becomes not an assassination attempt but an moment of black comedy when Avner's team is forced by circumstances to share a safe house with a group of PLO members. Avner has a conversation with a man who is clearly himself as a Palestenian, doing what he is doing in the hope for a home. Devoid of specific reference to ethnicity or religion, the words could be said (and have been said) by those on both sides.<br /><br />I am reminded of Lincoln's words during his Second Inaugural where he observed that both sides had prayed to the same God, because Arabs and Israelis do not believe that they pray to the same God. Each believes God has promised this dispute territory to them and them along, and the difference between these mirror beliefs that makes us think it will never be resolved in anything other than blood and death is that each holds that there God IS God. The judgment of Spielberg and this film is that the path taken by Avren and his men did not make things better. It is pointed out that those who replaced the dead escalated the violence and the Twin Towers remind us where this road has taken us without an end in sight. The great tragedy could well be that there is no end and suggesting that a particular course of action has made things worse is not a retroactive argument for having done nothing. What is happening could well be as foreordained as any Greek tragedy and those who feel \\"Munich\\" attacks them are projecting what they know in their souls onto what they see on the screen.se to the Olympic massacre. What I know about the true history is that they succeeded in killing many of their targets, who may or may not have been directly involved in Munich. Each believes God has promised this dispute territory to them and them along, and the difference between these mirror beliefs that makes us think it will never be resolved in anything other than blood and death is that each holds that there God IS God. B000E1ZBH2|5.0|I've read Jane Austin's Pride & Prejudice twice, seen the A&E mini-series with Colin Firth (love him!) and I've now seen Pride & Prejudice 2005 (about four times in one week). When Ms. Austin wrote Lizzy, she intended a character who was spunky, light hearted and very intelligent.  Ms. Knightly's portrayal of Lizzy matched what I had always imagined Lizzy being (and looking) like.<br /><br />Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfayden were by far breathtaking in the portrayals of their respective characters.  I was left breathless many times by the slight looks given by Matthew Macfayden and received by Keira Knightly.  Keira Knightly's performance of Lizzy's obvious hatred/affection for Mr. Darcy seeps through the screen into your own heart!  The passion of the 2005 movie version is undeniable!<br /><br />However, be aware that Hollywood did what Hollywood does best:  Fluffed it up and made it their own.  The mini-series version is so deep and involved with the original story line that it is totally engrossing.  However, the movie version brings the story to life with the passion and resonance that Ms. Austin intended.<br /><br />I would recommend watching both.  The mini-series for the depth of character development and strict storyline and the movie for the passion and moral awareness that this story was meant to portray.version brings the story to life with the passion and resonance that Ms. Austin intended. 0312995423|1.0|Although the technical details were engrossing, this book is not well-written enough to be enjoyable, and the action is jolting. Consider this: 128 chapters, each about a page to a page-and-a-half long. Each chapter alternates between the action at NSA (in America) and a bad-guy chase in Spain. With a page-long chapter, there's only enough time for a few actions, a few lines of dialogue in each. It also features a heroine who is not only brilliant but -- of course -- beautiful. It's never enough to have an intelligent woman; she has to be stunning and in her 30's as well. Yawn. <br /> <br />Susan, the heroine, ostensibly has an IQ of over 160, yet she misses plot points that have the reader groaning at their blatant self-evidence. When in an early chapter, her boss is explaining the details of a corporate double-cross, she answers him with wide-eyed questions. \\"...Different?\\" \\"...Unbreakable?\\" \\"What!?\\" <br /> <br />The plot's conclusion can be guessed long before the final chapters, and you are left with the impression that this novel was written with one objective: ultimately to look good on a movie screen. The characters are not developed and the dialogue is often laughable. I enjoyed \\"Da Vinci Code\\" as long as I overlooked the similarity of Brown's writing style to Sydney Sheldon's; but \\"Digital Fortress\\" has nothing going for it.
B000002IMG|5.0|If you enjoyed headbanging to The Legacy, then don't even think about whether or not you should get The New Order because I will answer that question for you right now: YES! This is another serving of pure and unadulterated thrash metal. Alex and Eric seemed to have kicked up the heaviness of their riffs a bit. They aren't as raw, but they seem to be a bit more aggressive. The songwriting is also a lot stronger on this album. It's just one year later and the band is already showing a good amount of growth.  <br /> <br />Eerie Inhabitants starts with slow and creepy guitar playing. Alex's solo has a very dark and shadowy sound, a great indicator of what the album sounds like. But don't let the slow intro fool you, this song picks up and gets into some heavy thrash. Chuck's singing kicks ass right from the start. My favorite line in this song is \\"Nobody listens to their CRYING!\\" Damn good shirek right there. Alex's solo is amazing and filled with melody. A very emotional sound. And it goes on for almost a whole minute! The New Order immediately showcases the talents of the great Alex Skolnick, as it opens with a killer guitar solo. Right after that, we get some pretty damn heavy riffs that beat you into the ground. For such a heavy song, it has some pretty catchy verses! Alex's solo starts off slow, but soon gets pretty wild while still sounding melodic. I am sure everyone knows Trial by Fire, as it is a Testament classic. It begins with a calm, melodic solo by Alex. But do not be fooled because the heavy riffs soon come in to kick some ass. The riffs may be heavy, but trust me they are still catchy. This song is a bit slower-paced, but don't worry because a fast one is up next: Into the Pit. It starts with some mean riffs, but the song soon speeds up and goes into headbanging mode. Louie's drum work on here is a highlight, and you gotta love Chuck's fast singing. I love the line \\"The mass production and the killing of all.\\" If you want metal that kicks the sh*t out of you, then just blast this song. And Alex's solos! These are good examples of fast-paced guitar solos! Nobody's Fault is an Aerosmith cover. I haven't heard the original, so I won't compare the two. But right away, you can tell the song has more of a hard rock feel rather than thrash metal. It's a pretty good tune, with some catchy guitar playing and some good high notes hit by Chuck. I like the way he sings the chorus, and the solos are played well.  <br /> <br />A Day of Reckoning starts with a cool solo, and then the riffs come to steal the show! A lot of people seem to think this song is filler, but I like it. It's pretty good and catchy metal. Hypnosis is a creepy instrumental. It is just a two minute guitar solo played by Alex, but it is amazing. It's very slow and filled with melody, albeit a creepy one! If you sit back and take this song in, then I warn you, you may get a few goosebumps. Disciples of the Watch starts with another creepy solo, but it sets the song very well. After a few heavy riffs, Louie kicks in with some awesome drumming and the pace picks up. Chuck does some fast singing, and on the line \\"I'll burn you to that cross\\", he gives us a good growl, which hints at how he would sing later on. I know I rant about Alex's solos a lot, but the one he does here is one of his best. It's fast and melodic, I haven't heard too many solos like that! The Preacher is another fast tune. It begins with an amazingly melodic and foreboding riff. Then Chuck belts out \\"THE PREACHER!\\" in that high voice we all know and love. The verses are sung pretty fast, this could very well be Chuck's fastest singing on the album. The riffs played before the solo and during the solo are very catchy. Chuck also gives us some sick shrieks at the end of the song, definitely some of his best. Musical Death (A Dirge) is another instrumental. It is very slow and the guitars have a beautiful sound. Definitely a great tune to kick back to on a cool and crisp day. Eric even gives us anifty little solo! Speaking of solos, Alex does some of his best work on this song, his solos can bring a tear to your eye if you are caught off guard. Even though it is a slow song, it ends the album wonderfully. <br /> <br />The Legacy was a tough album to surpass, but the boys managed. The New Order shows the talents of these guys even more than the debut did. Forget the sophomore slump curse, Testament weren't hit by that! It's a shame metal doesn't sound much like this anymore, a lot of the younger guys should take some notice. I guess all we can do is pray, but until then, we've got these great older albums to put on. Combine some great, melodic thrash metal with one of the coolest album covers, and The New Order proves to be one of the highlights of 1988!
0671799320|4.0|This is a thoroughly readable text starting with the discovery of oil in Titusville, Pennsylvania and ending with the Iranian revolution. I ponder what insight Yergin would bring to a follow-up book but he is secure resting on his laurels. This book is a must-read for anyone wishing to understand the power-struggles in the oil industry. As for shortages, Yergin suggests that there have been several. Once oil became scarce in Pennsylvania, which supplied kerosene for lamps throughout the world, new discoveries followed in turn-in Indonesia, in east Texas, Russia, Iraq, Iran, and the Arabian peninsula. It is small wonder that as the thirst for oil grew, we, in the modern world, became accustomed to new finds. Beyond the new discoveries, Yergin explains how Standard Oil of Indiana saved the day by developing, in the early 1900s, a new process for cracking oil to produce gasoline efficiently. Without this invention, the internal combustion engine would have stalled on the market-long before Henry Ford could dismiss his customer's complaint about the model T by saying, \\"They can have any color they want, as long as it's black.\\" This is also a story about interesting characters. The descriptions of Rockefeller, Getty and the founders of Shell and British Petroleum were very entertaining. But, I am forgetting the undertone in Yergin's book. I enjoyed the tales of how the thirst for oil affected the strategies of the warring parties during World War II. And, how political intrigue between the great powers (England, the US, and others), and the indigenous people, who owned the oil, worked to shape our modern world.<br /><br />Hey, if you found this helpful, please show your appreciation.

6305095442|4.0|Though this was not the first modern horror film to use parody (Dawn of the Dead, An American Werewolf in London are examples), the lengths to which is goes are wildly imaginative. Just like Re-Animator spoofed the sci-fi/horror genre, Evil Dead 2 takes on the slasher film genre and sends it up way before the Scream/I Know What You Did Last Summer/Scary Movie cash cows. For those who liked the \\"tree\\" sequence in the first Evil Dead movie, imagine it being magnified over and over again. Using the stop motion animation technique in a deliberately crude fashion, Evil Dead 2 is still wildly imaginative.  A person tries to fight off their own severed hand. Visions appear from nowhere. The first sequence in speeded up time is dizzily unnerving. If you don't like slasher films (believe me this is a hell of a lot better than any Friday the 13th film, take your pick) or if you're one of those old blue haired types ranting about \\"video nasties\\" then stay away. However, if you want a good, gorey and even sometimes scary descent into madness then Evil Dead 2 is for you. For real film fanatics, one might note (though on a far more intellectual level)the sense of the world collapsing and turning against the protagonist(s) of the film can also be found (albeit much more arty and far less gorey) in the films of Jan Svankmeyer. As for the casual horror buff, Evil Dead II is a classic of the subgenre of splatter films with a sense of humor which would be taken to new heights with Rob Zombie's \\"The Devil's Rejects\\". Leave the lights on.

B000E1ZBGS|3.0|I wanted to like this movie, and I was prepared to accept a less than strict adaptation of the book, but I couldn't forgive the ridiculously indecorous little additions to a work based so heavily on the complexities of manner and conduct in Austenian society.  I didn't mind the family's poorness being enhanced to bring understanding to a modern audience of the wide breach between Bennett and Darcy, but I thought Knightly's coarse, greasy banged version of the subtle and witty Elizabeth went beyond the boundaries of \\"youthful\\" or \\"exuberant\\" and marched straight into the realms of the just plain inelegant.  For example, who thought it would be cute for Knightly to smack her food and lick her fingers at the breakfast table?  That kind of thing has nothing to do with youth or a modern adaptation--it's rude even today.  A main part of the original story was that Elizabeth and Jane had manners far superior to their family's, and were not themselves the objectionable ones.  Darcy even says as much at one point, a comment which was included in the movie's dialogue but hardly demonstrated in its acting.     Elizabeth Bennett is one of my favorite literary characters, but all the things I like the most about her, her careful cleverness, her grace under fire, her classy superiority to the huffy rudeness dealt out to her by the upper class, were all but lost in this 'sassy farm girl meets stuck up rich dude' version of Austen's infinitely more subtle work.  In truth, this movie had a lot to live up to given the success of the BBC version (a fact which can be seen in its complete omission of that now famous scene where a dripping Darcy meets a shocked Elizabeth at his estate), but in my opinion, in its effort to do so, it simply overplayed its hand.
B000EULJLU|4.0|With all the negative reviews going around, I'll start off by saying that no, I am not a ToolSheep. With that said, I'm not going to take anything away from this one. <br /> <br />People posting reviews need to judge the album and not the band. I know there are a lot of ToolSheep on here who brag about Tool being the band of all bands, and that they saved the world again. Not quite. <br /> <br />My favourite songs on this album were Wings for Marie (pt 1) and 10,000 Days (Wings pt 2). Coincidentally, these two tracks were probably the most laid back and most anti-climactic songs on the record. This is what strikes me as interesting. I must say that one of the first things I noticed about this record was the lack of climactic interludes. Tool is known as a climactic band, one that \\"takes you somewhere.\\" A classic example is the song \\"Lateralis\\" off of the previous album. Listen to it and pay attention around the 7-minute mark and you will catch my drift. 10,000 Days doesn't really grasp climactica, if you will. This record is rather difficult to get into, even by Tool's standards. <br /> <br />I thought the riffs and the vocals for \\"Jambi\\" were excellent, complementing the opening song \\"Vicarious,\\" which is somewhat similar to Schism. I do, admittedly, notice some Lateralus on this album. A lot of it is subtle, though. Mostly a riff here and a passage there, but nothing too serious. <br /> <br />I think the lack of climax and the seemingly drawn-out experience of this album undermine it, or could undermine it, to say the least. I found myself waiting and waiting on certain tracks for something to happen - primarily in \\"Roseta Stoned,\\" \\"Right in Two,\\" and \\"Intension.\\" Now, \\"Roseta Stoned\\" did pick up nicely. \\"Right in Two\\" did so as well (although to a much lesser extent), but \\"Intension\\" hasn't done it for me. But I will tell you that \\"[Wings pt 1 and 2],\\" coupled with \\"Vicarious,\\" \\"Jambi,\\" \\"The Pot,\\" and \\"Roseta Stoned\\" make the album worth it for me. <br /> <br />It lacked climax. It lacked progression, and it seemed to give me a feeling of \\"Is this it?\\" upon my first listens, but it is a very good album in my opinion. The songs grow on you, and I found myself liking the tracks a lot sooner rather than later. In fact, I really didn't like \\"The Pot\\" too much at first (because of Maynard's voice at the beginning) but it is now one of my favourite songs.  <br /> <br />I guess this one was worth the wait. It's no Lateralus by any stretch of the imagination, but it is a very good record. It won't crack my top 3 for 2006 which is a disppointment on its own (in respect to Tool's standards), but I still enjoyed listening to it. Maybe it's because I'm not a Toolaholic I'm able to accept this album and find what I enjoy about it (without resorting to monumental expectation). I still expected post-Lateralus brilliance, but I didn't get it. However, I am not disappointed with this release. Good album. I'll listen to it plenty.

B000EULJLU|5.0|If there is one thing that has always been true about TOol it is that their songwriting and stylistic choices are flawless.  I have never heard a better band when it comes to developing a consistently powerful and moving shape for their sound, and that shape differs from album to album.  A lot of Tool fans seem to have forgotten this.  10,000 days blends the band's ambient and melodic sensibilities with the staccato math rock sounds of some of their notable opening acts from their last tour, like Meshugga and Fantomas.  What results is a consistently heavy and intimate sound, different from the distant ethereality of Lateralus, although comparisons are inevitable.  The band has evolved enough to no longer rely on the Build-up/Release pattern followed closely on Aenema and Lateralus, their songwriting has become much more flexible and mature.  I think it would be very easy for a band of TOol's talent to continue in the same vein as their previous works and maintain the support of many of their recently (relatively) acquired fanbase, but 10,000 days is an effort in a different direction.  I think it is as much more exciting and honest album because of this.

B000002KB8|5.0|Don't let anyone tell you any different. It all started here. Led Zeppelin, The Who, and even Pink Floyd are often cited as being prime influences on the then-fresh and evolving state of heavy metal, yet these comparisons are false, just about every band from the era being much more influenced by blues, early r&b, and their predecessors in the rock and roll community. While Sabbath are masters of all the above named crafts, their dark, occult-themed lyrics, Iommi's sludge-like but delightful guitar playing (especially for a guy missing two fingers!), Osbourne's once-upon-a-time demonic howls, and an extremely heavy for their time rhythm section, Sabbath holds all the trademarks of an early metal band moreso than anything else. Although it may sound primitive compared to today's standards of metal, where lightning fast, thunderous blastbeats and finger-twisting shredding are the norm for an exceptional metal band, the fact that none of these bands would be around today without the influence of this first record says much more about the band than their lack of virtuosity compared to todays standards. <br /> <br />This would be the worlds introduction to Ozzy Osbourne's trademark, off-key vocals, which since then have secured his place on the throne as the King of Darkness, and while Paranoid may be the definitive Sabbath album for many fans, the roots are really laid here, with this debut, indisputably one of the best from any band of the era. Tony Iommi's guitar playing is the definition of the era in which he became a legend, and his melodic if gritty riffing and sharp pentatonic solos are groundbreaking, keeping in mind that only recently before this albums release two fingers on his critical fretting hand had been torn off in a machine accident on the last day of his factory job. <br /> <br />Geezer Butler and Bill Ward are in my opinion one of the best rhythm sections in the classic rock era, second only to Bonham and Jones, Ward's drumming being truly ahead of its time. Going into a track by track review is pointless, as anyone who hasn't heard each and every one of these classics by now has been dwelling in caves for the last 40 years, but among my favorites are Wicked World, which features exceptional classical guitar picking to counter the rollicking blues riffing dominating the verses, the title track, whose sounds of thunder and ominous church bells would become staples of the metal scene in years to come, and The Wizard, upon which Osbourne's harmonica playing give the early metal ballad a decidedly unique back country twist. <br /> <br />Black Sabbath would go on to create many more great albums and many more unsatisfactory ones throughout their career, which was plagued by constant disputes within the original lineup before finally reuniting for their present day original arrangement, but this self titled record is the definitive moment when heavy metal was born. Slayer and Metallica may have taken it to the next level, and Zeppelin may get the credit for it, but this is truly the gem of the early metal scene which absolutely cannot be missed.

B000E6UK5K|4.0|...that hears Alan Parsons music throughout most of this CD?  Most Pink Floyd fans know Alan Parsons, if only through the terrific engineering work that he did in DSOTM.  David Gilmour also collaborated with Alan Parsons on the first cut of Parsons' latest effort, A VALID PATH.  This cut, entitled RETURN TO TRUNGUSKA is one of my favorites by either performer, and made me wonder why it took them so long to get together.  It was pure magic and the absolute highlight of A VALID PATH. <br /> <br />Then I purchased ON AN ISLAND and my first impression was that this is Gilmour's tribute to Alan Parsons.  I was stunned.  All the musical nuances were there, and much like Alan Parsons' later works, it took some time to warm up to several of the cuts on this album.  But warm up, I did.  I asked my son about this (he too is a big Pink Floyd and Alan Parsons fan), but he didn't see the similarities.  Perhaps you won't either, but to me there is little doubt. <br /> <br />ON AN ISLAND is not a typical Pink Floyd album.  There is little immediate \\"Floyd\\" gratification and entire CD is extremely laid back.  But it's full of rich, subtle textures, and of course is personified with the wonderful guitar work of Gilmour.  It begins with the soaring CASTELLORIZON, then blends in nicely with ON AN ISLAND (my personal favorite of this CD).  THE BLUE (more wonderful and soaring guitar work) would work very well on Alan Parson's ON AIR album.  TAKE A BREATH was the first cut that had no Alan Parsons in it and I found it impressive.  RED SKY AT NIGHT is highlighted with a haunting sax.  THIS HEAVEN is very bluesy with a Parsons' overtone.  THEN I CLOSE MY EYES once again shows subtle and beautiful guitar and piano work.  SMILE is even more subdued, yet I enjoyed it just the same.  A POCKETFUL OF STONES is pure Parsons' \\"B\\" material.  I suspect that by now many felt that this CD was dull.  WHERE WE START (the last cut on the CD) doesn't do anything to change this muted feeling, but damn ifI didn't end up enjoying this one as well.  There is a real \\"lonely\\" feeling throughout this work.  And while there is nothing near Gilmour's/Parsons' magnificent RETURN TO TRUNGUSKA that is on the Parsons' album, I found this latest work to be surprisingly satisfying. <br /> <br />Thanks, David (now hurry up and release PULSE!).  Between 1 and 10, I give ON AN ISLAND a pretty solid 8 (although I admit that on my first listening I would have been hard-pressed giving it a 6.  If you're looking for hard-hitting Pink Floyd, you won't find it anywhere on this CD.  For many, it may take some time and several hours of listening before fully appreciating this work. B000055Y0Y|5.0|A psycho (played by John Malkovich) plans to kill the President, and Clint Eastwood, an aging, almost over-the-hill secret service agent, is trying to stop him. Malkovich torments Eastwood - Eastwood was on duty protecting Kennedy when he was shot in Dallas, and he didn't react accordingly when the shots went off; Malkovich knows it and drives him batty about it. Eastwood's been carrying that psychological scar ever since, and now he has a chance to redeem himself.<br /><br />In many of Eastwood's movies it's hard to sympathize with him because he's either so cruel and antagonistic or else almost unscathingly superhuman; here he does win our sympathy because finally he IS more human and like the rest of us: he's out of shape, he gets the flu, it takes a while to win the girl (Rene Russo). It's a nice change. There is nothing unique about the story or the way the plot unfolds: crazy man on the loose, Eastwood and cops try to track him down - though it's done very well. The tension is maintained, yet the director (Wolfgang Petersen) takes time to develop the characters, especially Eastwood. Of course there's the wow finish: Eastwood takes the bullet meant for the President (he's only wounded), thus redeeming himself. It's a very well-done thriller; definitely worth a watch.

B00005ATZT|3.0|Anyone who truly enjoyed the TV series THE FUGITIVE, starring David Janssen as Dr. Richard Kimble, as I did (I still think it was one of the best dramatic series - ever), will probably be disappointed in this movie remake starring Harrison Ford as the maligned doctor intent on finding his wife's real killer, as I was. Tommy Lee Jones plays Lt. Gerard, the police officer determined to bring Kimble back after he escapes from prison (on the TV show he escaped after the train he and Gerard were riding transporting Kimble to prison wrecked). Kimble saw a one-armed man running from his house the night his wife was murdered, and is convinced he's the killer.<br /><br />The movie becomes nothing more than a thrill-packed chase flick (some might say that's enough). Jones's character is much more interesting than Ford's. Ford does some very improbable things, such as going back to the hospital while on the lam and going to the jail to talk to a suspect with one arm - things that would have been thought too crazy for the TV show audience (and rightly so). Janssen's portrayal of Kimble was superb: there was a constant nervousness about him, a relentless fear exuding from him as if expecting disaster around every corner, and a bone-weariness that captured Kimble and his dilemma perfectly. Ford displays none of those qualities, and comes across as a man who is out to prove his innocence, by golly, you wait and see -  despite the fact that it's almost a given from the start. And, of course, he does, and it's a dummy conclusion: it ends up he was the target of a drug scam by a big pharmaceutical company. What a drag. That never would have washed in the TV series.<br /><br />I would recommend the TV series over this movie any day, but unfortunately the TV series isn't available on DVD. Why that is I don't know, but I hope it becomes available soon. Real soon.

Hell.. if they could take every track and put it on one disk.. it could be considered a greatest hits album for all i cared. \\"Blood Sugar Sex Magic, Californication, and now Stadium Arcadium are easily my favorite albums. In a top 10 list. Stadium would easily be on top. Along with Foo Fighters, \\"the Colour and the shape\\" NIN \\"The Fragile\\" Pearl Jams \\"10\\" along with my 200+ artists that i love listening to. So they make a good standing in the top. What can i say, i love music. And i like to think that i have good taste. And if you think so.. Buy this album, tell your friends! Its about time artists are rewarded for making pure music. No politics, no preaching, nothing more than feel good music with the best musicians in the industry. Enjoy! <br />
B000E1155E|5.0|What a blast of fresh natural energy and variety, that rips and roars from the very beginning. \\"Whatever People say I am That's what I am not \\" by the Arctic Monkeys is an album with good songs and music from a bunch of guys who are just out of their teens. The singing is so natural, young and spontaneous. You sometimes get a feel that they are a mix of the band \\"Oasis\\" (for vocals) and the band \\"Offspring\\" when it comes to music but then, they are not. The Arctic Monkeys are original in their own way. The musicianship is top-notch with exciting guitar riffs, meaningful solo leads, lovely bass lines and good drumming. I watched some live footage of the band and the drummer is a must-watch/hear. Believe me his drum kit has only one tom! So much from such a modest set-up.  <br /> <br />Most of the songs on the album average 3 minutes or less in length. Short songs work and eventually what you get is 13 songs. Who said \\"13\\" was unlucky. Even the slow songs exude style. <br /> <br />My favourites are \\"When the Sun goes down\\", \\"Red Lights Indicate the Doors are secure\\", \\"A Certain Romance\\", \\"From Ritz to the Rubble\\", \\"Mardy Bum\\", \\"Riot Van\\" with a touch of melancholy in the last two. \\"Perhaps Vampires is a bit strong but..\\", \\"Fake tales of San Francisco\\" and \\"View from the afternoon, the\\" are contenders for second best songs. The rest are listenable too. <br /> <br />Lyrics are spontaneous and natural and certainly not Kitsch. And who says bands of the past cannot be jabbed at. Didn't we like it in the 70's when Mark Knopfler and Dire Straits jabbed at \\"..those trumpet playing bands...\\" in \\"Sultans of Swing\\". <br /> <br />So what can Coldplay learn from The Arctic Monkeys? Originality, of course!. AM are not copying another band or being someone else. If I were a member of Coldplay I would simply quit the band and become a fan of the Arctic Monkeys. Like another reviewer put it, hype is the only flaw of this band. Eagerly awaiting their next offering.

0345409671|5.0|After stalking and killing a ruthless but enthrallingly passionate mobster named Roger, Lestat is approached by his ghost. At the same time, he is becoming increasingly paranoid that he's being followed by the devil himself, and he is growing interested in Roger's daughter Dora, a devout and popular television evangelist, who he wants to spare from embarrassment. Lestat and his companions try to protect her \\"church\\" from the fact that her father was a killer.<br /><br />Eventually, Lestat meets the devil, who calls himself \\"Memnoch\\". He takes Lestat on a whirlwind tour of heaven, hell, and the main epochs in the evolution of the universe. The tour offers a retelling of the entirety of biblical history from the devil's point of view in an effort by Memnoch to convince Lestat to join him in a noble quest. In his journey, Memnoch claims he is not evil but merely working for God by ushering lost souls into Heaven. Lestat is left with the confused choice of whether he will help the devil or not.<br /><br />After the tour, Lestat believes himself to have had a major revelation. Among other things, he believes that he has seen Christ's crucifixion and that he has received Veronica's Veil; he has also lost an eye in Hell. He tells his story to Armand, David, and Dora, who have joined him in New York. Dora and Armand are deeply affected upon seeing the veil; Dora takes it and reveals it to the world, and Armand goes into the sun in order to convince people that a miracle has occurred.<br /><br />At the end of the novel, Lestat and David go to New Orleans, where Maharet returns Lestat's eye to him along with a note from Memnoch. This note reveals that Memnoch may have been manipulating Lestat to serve his own agenda. Lestat then loses control of himself and Maharet is forced to chain him in the basement of the St. Elizabeth's convent, which is owned by the vampires, so that he will not hurt himself or others. When he is at last released, Lestat enters a prolonged coma on the floor of St. Elizabeth's (in which he remains for the next few installments of the Vampire Chronicles).<br /><br />It is later stated that during Lestat's coma, he is actually outside of his body. During which, he is forced into labor by angelic beings (stated in Blackwood Farm).<br /><br />Although the novel fits in the Vampire Chronicles storyline, the vast majority of it consists of the \\"tour\\" Memnoch gives Lestat of heaven, hell, and of the cosmology and theology behind it all.<br /><br />The novel follows up on claims made by David Talbot in The Tale of the Body Thief that God and the devil are on better terms than most Christians believe; it also reinterprets biblical stories to create a complete history of Earth, Heaven, and Hell that fits neatly with the history of vampires given in The Queen of the Damned.<br /><br />Reference:[...]<br /><br />This book is truly inspiring,I would recommend it to new and old readers alike,enjoy...Nigeln the floor of St. Elizabeth's (in which he remains for the next few installments of the Vampire Chronicles). <br /> <br />It is later stated that during Lestat's coma, he is actually outside of his body. My writing has been widely published, and my articles are often praised for their clarity. The clarity comes from Minto, plain and simple.

B0000033P0|5.0|There is nobody, NO-BOD-Y, better at the keyboards than Keith Emerson. This has been proven on every album ELP's ever released, from the first eponymous one with \\"Lucky Man\\" on it, to \\"Love Beach\\". How this man keeps from getting carpal tunnel syndrome, I'll never know, for the aural histrionics are incredible! On this album, their second and one of their best, the magic of Lake's sonorous, nasal low tenor, Emerson's adeptness and overdubbing and Palmer's percussive punctuation, helps the ELP formula take shape, though there isn't a classical cover here, like there is on the first album,\\"Trilogy\\" and \\"Love Beach\\", but there is \\"The Only Way\\" and \\"Time and Space\\", which SORTA sound classical.<br /><br />Has anybody ever noticed how much Greg Lake looks like etchings or paintings of protestant reformer Martin Luther? He seems to have the same sort of fire the medieval rabble-rouser had in his vocals as well, like he's trying to foment demonstrations all over the place in the group's songs. But the scary thing is how the entire group looks like they just stepped out of the road company cast of \\"Lord of the Rings\\" or a very grand Dungeons and Dragons game! Chances are ELP was and has been the Muzak of the D&D crowd for years, anyway, so it all fits!<br /><br />The grand work on this album, \\"Tarkus\\" takes up the first side, going from the track \\"Eruption\\" to \\"Aquatarkus\\", whatever that is, but you don't care what it's about, you just groove to the stream-of-consciousness rant of Lake's singing and Emerson's mind-boggling keyboard work.<br /><br />It turns out that \\"Tarkus\\" is the name of that strange combination creature on the cover of the album, an armadillo with the bottom half of a Sherman tank, who is an analogy of the brutality of war. Another creature, called a Manticore, (at one time, the name of the label WEA Records allowed ELP to form for its releases,) drives this marauding juggernaut away, saving the people and the countryside from its destruction. You know what...you really couldn't care less about this tale! You just groove on the incredible music and talent involved in the production! This album, along with \\"Trilogy\\", \\"Emerson, Lake & Palmer\\", \\"Love Beach\\" and perhaps \\"Brain Salad Surgery\\" are among the best things you will ever hear issue out of a hi-fi speaker, classical, rock, jazz or otherwise...<br /><br />The second side has the incredible \\"The Only Way\\", a song that asks the musical question: \\"Can You believe...God makes you breathe? How did he lose...six million jews?!\\" and my personal favorite from the album, \\"Bitches' Crystal\\", a song apparently celebrating the world of, you guessed it, DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS!! With a \\"heretic priestess\\", tortured spirits that cry and ghostly images dying, the arrangement sees Emerson flashing his fingies across the piano keys like some unreal Padarewski, faster than anybody I've ever heard play keyboards.<br /><br />Save up your shekels, and buy \\"Emerson, Lake and Palmer\\", \\"Tarkus\\", \\"Trilogy\\", Brain Salad Surgery\\", and \\"Love Beach\\", and just sit back and be dazzled by some of the best musicianship to see a Billboard chart!<br /><br />I really can't praise these guys enough!dn't care less about this tale! You just groove on the incredible music and talent involved in the production! This album, along with \\"Trilogy\\", \\"Emerson, Lake & Palmer\\", \\"Love Beach\\" and perhaps \\"Brain Salad Surgery\\" are among the best things you will ever hear issue out of a hi-fi speaker, classical, rock, jazz or otherwise...    The second side has the incredible \\"The Only Way\\", a song that asks the musical question: \\"Can You believe...God makes you breathe? How did he lose...six million jews?!\\" and my personal favorite from the album, \\"Bitches' Crystal\\", a song apparently celebrating the world of, you guessed it, DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS!! With a \\"heretic priestess\\", tortured spirits that cry and ghostly images dying, the arrangement sees Emerson flashing his fingies across the piano keys like some unreal Padarewski, faster than anybody I've ever heard play keyboards. I really can't praise these guys enough!

0007179731|5.0|This is an interesting story. It is a story of a lawyer who appears to have it all - the corner office, the life style, the cars, women, ... Then he gives it all up and tours the East. While there he comes across this strange monk and monastery. He comes to live life in a much different way. Yet he is challenged by the monk who has trained him to go back home and share the message he has learnt, with the West. Julian, our main character, returns to his old law firm and to his prot?g? John. He tells him a parable; then the rest of the book explains the parable and how it relates to different aspects of our lives. The parable is rather simple and a little strange but as it is explained you will never forget it. Read it to find out how a garden, lighthouse, sumo wrestler, pink wire cable, stopwatch, roses and a winding path of diamonds are symbols of timeless principles and virtues by which to live your life. This book could help raise the quality of your life to a new level.

B000EULJLU|5.0|As other reviewers have stated, you shouldn't be quick to judge 10,000 Days after just one listen. B000F7CMRM|5.0|Syriana is an eye-opening look at the nature of the international oil industry. The film has the feel of a behind the scenes documentary where the viewer is able to watch key players abuse authority, power, position, etc. to make as much dough as possible while keeping as much oil as possible flowing into the U.S.    Extraordinarily prescient, given the fact that the Middle East has passed their Peak Oil Production (including Saudia Arabia some time between 2002 and 2006), as we had done in the early 70's (around the time of the oil crisis) and Russia had in the 80's. The North Sea is also virtually used up. With China and India soon to overtake American consumers as the chief abusers of this quickly depleting natural resource, it is no wonder why we are witnessing the U.S. government taking over one of the largest oil producers in the world, and another big oil producer attempting to arm itself with nukes in order to prevent the U.S. from attempting to 'steal' or manipulate their oil situation. Without oil, modern American society would alter dramatically in a verynegative way and that is why some believe that it is necessary to do absolutely whatever it takes to grab our share of oil - even if it means the unlawful invasion of a sovereign nation.    And that is what Syriana shows - unscrupulous, corrupt sociopaths murdering and screwing everybody over for every last barrel they can get before it runs out.    I understand that many Americans *choose* to ignore or disbelieve that oil is indeed running out with all major oil fields having surpassed their peaks (which doesn't mean we are only halfway through it, as anywhere up to the last 10-25% of a given oil field is extremely poor quality not to mention more expensive to extract as could ever possibly be gained on the market).  It is a scary thought, and people *choose* to ignore facts. Ignorance is bliss, as they say. And these ignorant types, of course, won't like Syriana.
B000EMGAOY|5.0|The Chili Peppers deliver their best CD in what many thought was the twilight of their career. How good is Stadium Arcadium? It's a stunner because it serves the expected and unexpected in equal portions. The Peppers have never sounded so pop (that's a good thing). The original yet limited punk-funk act has flowered into perhaps the most diverse band in America. Couple that with musicianship that is second to none and you get a four-headed monster primed for chart domination. Anthony Kiedis singing (once a weakness) has never been better. Flea and Chad Smith are untouchable as rhythm making madmen. But the star of this inner-space journey is John Frusciante. His playing is reaching a level that almost has me using the H-word (Hendrix!). He is one of the few guitarists who can play with quiet beauty (Stadium Arcadium), crunching funk (Hump de bump) and hard rock power and grace (throughout both discs). It's a performance for the ages (rock, that is) and he will finally get the recognition he deserves. Flea said it best: If you don't like the new record then you don't like RHCP. It's all here: radio friendly peppers (Dani California), slow thoughtful peppers (Slow Cheetah) and bust a nut PEPPERS (Tell Me Baby, Readymade). Stadium Arcadium is their masterpiece; enjoy...

B000002KIE|5.0|This is a truly unique album. It's the only record they made, and it's the only one they needed to make. This is a totally 1970's hardrock album, but like nothing else that came out in that decade (even compared to the other punk albums of the time). What the likes of The Stooges, Alice Cooper, Ziggy Stardust-era David Bowie, and the New York Dolls started in the early-7O's, the Pistols picked up on and made trashier and nastier. If you're looking for pristine production value, great musicianship, and poppy sounding vocals then D0N'T BUY THIS ALBUM - it's Punk Rock after all!!! But that's not to propigate the myth that these guys had no musical talent. Guitarist Steve Jones knew how to bust out the power-chords and old fashion Chuck Berry riffs and solos. Yeah, that's not the most complicated stuff, but that doesn't matter, it sounded damn good! And singer Johnny Rotten was the perfect \\"angry youth\\" frontman. The annoying, pissed off voice mixed with the politically tinged, smarmy, sarcastic, and offensive lyrics is brilliant! The two most well known songs from the album, \\"Anarchy In The UK\\" and \\"God Save The Queen\\", aren't the best tracks here, and over the past 30 years have overshadowed the rest of the album - which is all great. There isn't a single bad song on Nevermind The Bollocks. \\"Bodies\\" (about a woman getting an abortion) is probably still one of the most offensive songs ever written. In \\"New York\\" Johnny Rotten takes on this 195O's-rock style crooning when he sings the chorus which is classic. And now, nearly 20 years after the fall of communism and the Berlin Wall, there's still something menancing and sinister about the jackboot marching intro to \\"Holiday In The Sun\\". The album was almost entirly the product of Steve Jones and Johnny Rotten. Yeah, Paul Cook played drums, but bassist Glen Matlock was gone by this point, and they wouldn't let Sid Vicious play bass because he sucked. And while Malcom McLaren may have been the overbearing, string-pulling manager, he had almost nothing to do with how this album ended up sounding (the story is that he thought it sounded horrible). Some of the material on Nevermind The Bollocks is dated (it came out in 1977 after all), but the Jones/Rotten/Cook touch makes it still very entertaining today. The mythology surrounding the bizzarre story of the Sex Pistols has given rise to a lot misinformation. This is very clear by the ton of wrong stuff in many of the reviews I've read here on Amazon, intersetingly enough mostly by the people who have only negative things to say about the Pistols. So seriously, actually listen to the album and get your facts straight before writing a review - and just because you're only 16 is no excuse!
1594200823|4.0|A well-written, informative, and at times disturbing book.  It's scary to contemplate how distanced we've become from our food sources, and the consequences this distance has for our planet, animal welfare, our own health, and our future.  I do quibble with some of his statements about vegetarianism, as does another reviewer above.  Perhaps Pollan was in a bit of a rush to return to his meat-eating ways.  Meat-eating may be our natural state, though our current habits of meat-eating are far from natural.  Pollan does a great deal more to illustrate this point than he does to detract from it by his potentially misinformed statements on the vegetarian and vegan causes.  Overall, I highly recommend this book.

158234082X|5.0|Tony Bourdain is a smart, witty, funny, and deeply twisted individual, and is also a first-rate writer whose non-fiction is as entertaining and expressive as any novel I have ever read. I first became aware of Tony through his cable television show \\"No Reservations\\" (which is the only television show that I go out of my way to see each week.) I immediately bought this book after seeing the episode on Icelandic cuisine, as I thought he was intelligent yet not another insufferable food snob. He is a man who wants to try everything and has absolutely no fear or prejudices about food and excels at telling it like it is.<br /><br />This book recounts his life and career rising to the top of the pack in the culinary world. It is a deeply personal and unvarnished look at the world of big-league professional food, and is full of insights on both food and the restaurant business. When I was younger I worked as a line cook in a relatively nice restaurant. Although my experience was somewhat less frenetic and more sanitary than the scene in New York, I can certainly attest that the cast of characters (and their flaws) revealed in this book is right on the money.<br /><br />One thing I like about Bourdain and this book is that he tells the truth even when it's ugly. He explains why, for instance, not to order meat well done or why not to even think about ordering fish on Monday. (He's right on both accounts.) He doesn't dodge his own past when others would fail to mention diversionary activities such as a heroin addiction, and even though he comes across as cantankerous, he is a guy you can take at his word.<br /><br />Some of this book is pure gold, not just for cooks and would be chefs, but for everyone. His writing (\\"Rules to Live By,\\" page 64, and \\"A Commencement Address,\\" page 293 in particular) is excellent and applies to any profession. He also shares many inside secrets of Les Halles (and other restaurants he has worked at), of winning \\"mise-en-place\\" (or just \\"meez;\\" people who really want to cook professionally should take this to heart), and technical opinions (why and how to use an offset serrated knife.)<br /><br />This book is coarse and not for the faint of heart, but if you really want to know about cooking or cooks, it is the best (and funniest) single volume ever written. I highly recommend this bookeople who really want to cook professionally should take this to heart), and technical opinions (why and how to use an offset serrated knife.)<br /><br />This book is coarse and not for the faint of heart, but if you really want to know about cooking or cooks, it is the best (and funniest) single volume ever written. I highly recommend this book

B0009X7664|5.0|<br />A Reflection Of Our Lives  <br /> <br />The following May 2006 review of \\"To Kill A Mockingbird\\" is an update to my prior January 2000 review of the same movie. This updated review refers to the superior \\"Legacy Series Edition\\" of the movie which is now the preferred DVD purchase choice. The \\"Legacy Series Edition\\" includes notably better sound options (Dolby Digital 5.1) than previous editions (such as the \\"Collectors Edition\\") as well as various `extras' now included in the \\"Legacy\\" two disc set. The `5.1 sound option' alone is worth upgrading to the \\"Legacy Series Edition\\" and many fans will appreciate the new `extras' included on the new version. Now, on to the movie (and the book)...  <br /> <br />\\"To Kill a Mockingbird\\" is a timeless classic, displayed in breathtaking imaginative and visual beauty whether you read the book or watch the movie. Either genre brings to life the old south, its charm, its bigotry, its prejudice, its fear of the unknown, and ultimately its triumph of the human soul.  <br /> <br />There is a beauty to both the movie and the book which seems to change as one grows older. The timelessness of the movie/book is evidenced on two different levels. Both are appreciated today as much as when they were originally released. Perhaps more importantly, children under the age of 10 identify with the book or movie as only a child can. As one grows older, you see the movie/book through the eyes of an adult and from a different perspective. A parent can also appreciate the movie, reliving it through their own children's eyes.  <br /> <br />The BOOK is essentially the 'coming of age' of Jem as he slowly leaves his childhood behind and begins to understand the harsh realities of life in the deep South. The MOVIE more represents the 'coming of age' of Scout as she views the black and white realities which slowly surround her. Scout's innocence reminds adults of their moral code and conduct in the movie, the book, and (surprisingly) in real life. She is able to center us on our own humanity as is witnessed in many scenes; chiefly in the (midnight) jail scene where she single handedly (and unknowingly) stops a lynching by simply saying `hello' to someone she recognizes in the lynch mob.  <br /> <br />Ultimately, I suppose, the movie represents our 'coming of age', as a child, as an adult, as individuals, and as a society. Each of us must decide whether we will take up the hangman's noose or drop the rope in favor of the child within.  <br /> <br />On a different level, Boo Radley represents all of these same fears, prejudices, and bigotry ingrained within America, North and South. Only when we finally meet Boo for the first time, do we recognize a human face, a protector, a neighbor, rather than the devil himself. Scout and Jem's journey is also our journey, one in which we all make. Some choose to see the fearful murderer who lives in the Radley house, while others choose to see the human being and ultimately reach out to say \\"Hey Boo...\\"  <br /> <br />In this black and white book, in this black and white movie, in this black and white world, there will always be a Bob or Mayella Ewell. Fortunately, there will also be a Boo, an Atticus, a Tom, a Jem, or a Scout. Hopefully they will be there for each of us when we \\"waked up in the morning...\\"  <br />

0684824906|5.0|Doris Kearns Goodwin has written what is possibly the best book of the year.  This is well deserving of the praise it has received since its issue.  _Team of Rivals_ is not a typical biography, nor is it a history of the Civil War era.  It is, instead, a study of how Abraham Lincoln brought together a diverse group of people who in many cases were personally opposed to each other and forged them into a team.  This book shows how Lincoln turned opponents into partners, disparagers into praisers, and potential enemies into allies.  Ms. Goodwin has a terrific writing style, and it took an effort to actually put the book down for the evening.  I was actually sorry the book ended because it was so enjoyable to read.  It is richly detailed with many items that are little known and brought together here for the first time.  Ms. Goodwin has decisively proved the Lincoln theme has not been exhausted.

B000002HJR|5.0|being an avid fan of pantera from day one, i had read in early '95, i believe, an advertisement in some mag. about Phil Anselmo's new side band Down, was releasing an album/cd of heavy, Sab. like metal. i new at that point that is was going to be a good one. you know how you often can't wait for a new title to be released, then are a little disappointed when you buy it, and listen to it? well, let's just say the opposite happened here. i was literally blown away! this is surely one of the best releases of the '90's, and maybe one of the best heavy releases of the last 20 years. sludgy, riff laden, well engineered, you name it, it has it. having owned over 2,000 titles from the last 30 years or so, this ranks right up there with some of the best. check it out. i have turned more people on to this cd than probably any other, and none have been disappointed, or thought i over-hyped it's merits. read the reviews. see if i'm lyin' to ya, then buy it, and join the club. peace.
0876855575|5.0|Like most of his books this is loosely based on Bukowskis real life experiences. Ham on Rye covers Bukowskis childhood and early adulthood, ending around his second year of college. Even though he had a pretty terrible childhood if your to believe this book he finds a lot of humor in some very horrid situations. I found myself laughing out loud constantly while reading this, so this is not some depressing whine fest. Even though its sad at times its also a VERY funny book. One slightly annoying thing is, even though he paints himself as the ultimate loser in virtually every facet of life he does not seem to be able to resist the urge to paint himself as a tough guy straight out of a corny Hollywood movie. Never losing a fight in his teen years, crushing an ape like college football player during a pick up football game, and even telling the ridiculously unlikely story of beating up a professional boxer in a backyard boxing match, even though he had never trained, been an athlete or even had a pair of boxing gloves on in his life! But besides that slight annoyance this book is a truly great read.
B000EULJLU|5.0|I have been listening to Tool since the early 90's and have truly enjoyed every CD they have released.  I was really anxious to hear 10,000 Days and picked it up as soon as I could.  I was not a bit disappointed. <br /> <br />Having since gone through and read a number of reviews saying this disc didn't make any strides forward or that it isn't as good as Aenima, I just had to tell my opinion. <br /> <br />I think alot of people have missed alot of the things that Tool have done on this album that makes it sound different than any other.  The complex song structures and time signatures are still there, but they have gone further with their sound.  As everyone by now knows, Adam used a talk-box on this album, which I think was a perfect addition to the guitar solo on \\"Jambi\\".  Also, Maynard has obviously tried to expand his vocal abilities (\\"The Pot\\") which, in my opinion, adds more character to the sound and really changes the song from what it might have been.  Additionally they have mixed the vocals to be more on the same level as the rest of the band so as to make the vocals almost an instrument themselves.  Lastly, I commend Maynard for \\"Wings For Marie\\" and \\"10,000 Days\\".  They are for the most part \\"softer\\" songs, but listening to the lyrics makes them both amazing pieces of art and a fitting tribute to his mother. <br /> <br />As is usual with Tool CD's, it takes a while to get the full effect and really appreciate what they have created.  But after just a couple listens, you really start to realize what a great album this is.  And to all those that have criticized them for not being heavy or anything like that, Tool doesn't make their music to please everyone.  They make their music because it is what they feel and enjoy (just read some interviews).  On a side note, I encourage any Tool fans to pick up the latest edition of Guitar World.  The interview with Adam will give you a good taste of what they are doing musically and what they wanted to accomplish onthis disc.  <br /> <br />I think Tool has once again created another wonderful piece of art (CD and artwork) and 10,000 Days was worth every penny.

B000EMGAOY|4.0|The Red Hot Chili Peppers invented the rap/metal genre a good decade before the term was coined, not that the band's music is simplistic as the sub-genre would suggest as the Peppers also include elements of funk and jazz among others. This could explain how the band has survived, releasing nine albums as other rap/rockers like Limp Bizkit and Korn have disappeared into virtual obscurity. And the Peppers add to their funky legacy with Stadium Arcadium. <br /> <br />But ever since John Frusciante rejoined the band, the Peppers have gone on a mellower path with their last albums, Californication and By the Way. And even though Rick Rubin, who was at the help of the break out album, Blood Sugar Sex Magic, is back, the band continues the softer terrain. Even the louder songs on the set never reach the bombast of Give it Away or other songs that go even further back in their catalog. Lyrically, Anthony Kiedis also shows growth from the guy who was the master of the single entendre fifteen years ago (although the jury's still out on how dirty She's Only 18 is, but Hump de Bump isn't as suggestive as you might think). Of course they had to grow up sometime because no one wants to see a dude on the wrong side of forty wearing nothing but a sock. Then again, I don't want to see that from a dude on the right side of forty. But anyways. <br /> <br />If there is a downside to Staduim Arcadium is that, like almost every double album, it is way too long clocking in at over two hours and twenty-eight tracks. Then again the album doesn't plunge into the pit falls that has brought down other recent double disks by not dividing the album into specific genres like party songs and slow jams so both disk sounds like two full length Pepper albums, and the two disks, Mars and Venus, have no intrinsic means to them. As expected with this many tracks, there are a few songs that quickly got old and I found my skipping songs like Snow (Oh Now) and So Much I after a few listenings. <br /> <br/>Other songs have a very distinct Peppers song so much that when I first heard Tell Me Baby I thought it was Don't Stop. There a few songs that utilizes a horn sections reminiscent to elder funker Parliament and much to the pleasure of Christopher Walken, Readymade has a killer cowbell part. But in the end, the set could have been scaled down to a single disk, although not getting rid of the up tempo songs, as there were too many mid tempo songs bogging down the two disks.

At the end, you could have everything figured out in your head weeks after, and still not be satisfyed with your own explanation. Be prepared to think. B000ETQRCM|5.0|When I first reviewed Pearl Jam I was caught up in the excitement of the band, in my opinion, releasing their first great record since Yield. Over the last month of consistent listening to the album, I feel this has the chance to be something special in the Pearl Jam catalogue.<br /><br />The beauty of Pearl Jam is how each song demands your attention in much the same way Ten does. Peal Jam has a complete 1 to 13 feel to it that as the weeks have passed has a way of demanding continued spins on the stereo.<br /><br />The reason I beleive is that while the music is at first energetic and accessible, the songs have a meaty undercurrent provided by Eddie Vedder's spot on lyrics. Unemployable is a great example of this, at first I was grabbed by its bouncy feel and pop sensibility, but the tale of middle class worker being bounced from his job has a way of changing your original impresion as what first feels like a light pop hit is actually a Sprinsteen like tale of middle class frustration.<br /><br />The same goes for the opening string of hard rockers that blasts the record off, at first the sheer energy of the guitar playing grabs your eardrums, but at the core of each tune are some very descriptive lyrics that alter your original impression of the tunes. What at first seem like simply uptempo rock n roll are actually spot on rants describing some disturbing tales based in our modern culture. Severed Hand in particular has grown in terms of my fondness as the story of a woman appearing to hear of the death of her husband grows more rivetting with each listen.<br /><br />In time I beleive this album has the chance to stand up as one of the band's best ever.
B000002P72|5.0|Absolutely one of the finest live albums of all times.  I bought this album because it was listed as one of the top 100 guitar albums of all time in Guitar Player Magazine.  You get lightning in a bottle here with BB King at the height of his powers.  The audience is alive and you can feel the young woman hyperventilating and swooning to BB King's rendition of some blues classics.  His voice is flawless, still velvety smooth, especially when compared with later live albums by BB King.  There is the perfect mixture of BB King's introductions or setups for each tune, guitar, vocals and audience reaction.  The sound is immaculate, balanced and clear. His guitar playing is efficient and his timing is perfect.  It makes you wonder why more recent \\"live albums\\" lack the spontaneity and quality found in this recording.  The only regret is the album is not longer.

Rob's co-workers provide some hefty laughs with their top 5 lists, sarcasm and realistic portrayal of music geeks. Rob himself supplies many laffs with his self effacement and irony. And the turns the story takes itself are sometimes hilarious, sometimes just strange.( Wait til you find out what happens at the funeral of Rob's ex's father)<br /><br />The poignancy and depth of the book sneaks up on ya. One minute your chuckling over Rob's frustration with fans of Phil Collins, the next your sharing in a truthful,sometimes almost brutally so, insight into his mind.<br /><br />I guess what I'm trying to say is that any book that can take a self -obsessed guy's ruminating on music,relationships and life in general, and keep me interested because of the humor and truthfulness of the inner and outer dialogues, is a damn fine book. Try it. It makes soul searching fun!!!

B000EULJLU|5.0|This is music that challenges the senses, common thought processes, and anything generally perceived as 'normal'...What i like about Lateralus and now this cd is that it is an experience..Preconceived notions about what music should sound like must be thrown out the window, to even have a glimpse of understanding this kind of art...it is music to be appreciated..Personally i love it, it has a life of its own. Outstanding tempo changes, subtle textures, and incredible chemistry between the band members highlight this album..You can't compare this kind of music to any other, including Lateralus..because like Lateralus it takes TIME.  Time tells everything, and this is music that grows on you, or at least on me.  I give it 5 stars because it is BOLD, challenging, intelligent art.  Its not for everybody.  This is the first review I've ever written and i felt compelled to, because it was irritating reading other peoples comments on this cd, because its not what they 'expected'..I feel you can't expect anything from a band like TOOL, you just open your mind and listen.  This is real music from real geniuses, pure art.

B000EDWKXI|4.0|Let's get one thing clear right off the bat: I really, really, really enjoy Lasse Hallstrom's films. The Cider House Rules, The Shipping News (one of my all time favorites), Chocolat, and What's Eating Gilbert Grape are a few that stand out. So I went into this movie expecting the typical Lasse-style film ...and I wasn't disappointed.<br /><br />For those looking for a historically accurate recounting of Casanova's life, you best look elsewhere; this movie only touches on a few aspects of the great lover. Here we get a fun, raucous comedy with cinematic character (all filmed on location in Venice) along with sumptuous sets and startling costumes.<br /><br />Heath Ledger (Brokeback Mountain, 2005) plays the starring role and does so with a wit and charm reserved for such a part. Indeed, I'm becoming more and more impressed with Mr. Ledger. His ability to play a confused gay cowboy in one film, then a slight historical figure in the next speaks well for his future acting career.<br /><br />The story...<br /><br />Casanova's life is in jeopardy. The Prince of Venice has been covering for Casanova's immoral behavior (fornicating and adulterating) but the Catholic Church has had enough. Inquisitor Pucci (played perfectly by the baritone-voiced Jeremy Irons) has come to Venice to hang the famed lover of women. But confusion reigns as Casanova misdirects the Inquisitor by taking on the (phony) mantle of Paprizzio, a famed pork lard salesman. Oliver Platt (again, perfectly cast) nearly steals the show as the real - and rotund -Paprizzio who comes to Venice to marry the beautiful Francesca Bruni (Sienna Miller). Casanova falls in love with Francesca while Paprizzio falls for another. But Casanova is promised to another \\"virgin\\" whom he must marry in order to save his neck. Can he go against his womanizing behavior and get married? Is his affection for Francesca just another set of desires? Or could it be true love?<br /><br />Against all of this slapstick behavior is the beautiful backdrop of Venice. Its amazing streets, waterways, ancient buildings with staggeringly beautiful edifices, and, of course, the usual Lasse Hallstrom direction of all of it; this is what Mr. Hallstrom loves more than anything else: letting the settings become a character themselves.<br /><br />This isn't to say the movie is perfect. It isn't. The script, although holding its own charm, was fairly shallow and predictable. For instance, when Paprizzio is rebuffed by Francesca, his future wife, everyone knows that Paprizzio will find another mate close by.<br /><br />But even so, the film is packed full of great dialogue, great sets, even better costumes, and some wonderful actors (How could you possibly dislike a film with Oliver Platt, Jeremy Irons, Lena Olin, and Heath Ledger in it?) History buffs should avoid the film like the plague, but if you like slight comedies and, in particular, have enjoyed the Lasse Hallstrom films listed above, you'll delight in this flick. No doubt about it...ior is the beautiful backdrop of Venice. Its amazing streets, waterways, ancient buildings with staggeringly beautiful edifices, and, of course, the usual Lasse Hallstrom direction of all of it; this is what Mr. Hallstrom loves more than anything else: letting the settings become a character themselves.  <br /> <br />This isn't to say the movie is perfect. No doubt about it...

078681859X|5.0|Many of the fantasy books that come out sound pretty much the same, even more so now since the booming popularity of the Harry Potter series which are excellent in my opinion.  They are filled with young majicians who have to save the world from corrupt adult majician who only care about power and money.  The amulet of Samarkand is repetitive when it comes to the main plot of the story but it's written in a way that's different than any of the books I've read, and in this case change is good.  The book flipflops from Nathinial who is the young wizard who has to save London, and Bartimaeus, a 5000 year old djini he has summoned.  Nathanials chapters are in third person and Bartimaeus' chapters are in first person, not to mention the very comical footnotes from Bartimaeus clarifying himself and giving you background info on other demons and such.  I am not one to laugh while I am reading, even if I find something funny but I gave a chuckle or two while reading this one.  I'm not going to go into the story, you can read all about that in other reviews, I will say that I finished this book in about a week which for me is fast b/c I don't read every day.  People who pick this book up thinking it's going to be the next Harry Potter will be disappointed, this book isn't Harry Potter and the author isn't J.K. Rowling.  It's the Amulet of Samarkand by Jonathan Stroud, I think people who pan the book forget that.  It's an excellent book and I have bought book 2 \\"The Golem's Eye\\" and can't wait for it to get here so I can start reading it.
